awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Enhancing Undergraduate Experiences in Mobile Cloud and Data Security
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site award provides funding for the renewal of an outstanding REU site at Indiana University - Purdue University Indianapolis.   The site will recruit undergraduates from across the nation to participate in research topics related to cybersecurity, mobile cloud security, and data security and privacy. The research projects focus on issues related to the use of mobile devices such as smart phones and the secure use of mobile clouds to access, manage, store, and secure digital assets. Mobile cloud security is an area of current interest that is well-suited to undergraduate research productivity. The students will use controlled and competitive test environments to experiment with cyber-attack and defense techniques needed to secure the mobile devices that are pervasive in our society.  This site should help develop a group of computing professionals who can develop the systems of the future that impact society and enhance our quality of life. The REU experience provides students with the foundations and inspiration to pursue computing careers and research in areas that are rapidly evolving and impacting all of our citizens.  

This project is led by an outstanding team offering state-of-the art facilities and professional mentors to guide undergraduates in explorations of cutting-edge problems related to mobile cloud security. Students will learn how to use current tools and techniques to solve those problems that have direct impact on people.  The team will use proven strategies to recruit undergraduate students from groups traditionally under-represented in computer science including African American, Hispanic and female students.   The students will participate in research and professional development activities all designed to achieve the goals of retaining and graduating undergraduate students in computer science and engineering, recruiting students from groups traditionally under-represented in computing fields, and increasing recruitment of students into graduate programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this REU Site was to provide undergraduate students with hands-on research experience in mobile cloud and data security. Each year, 10 undergraduate students from across the nation were recruited to participate in an intensive 10-week summer program at Indiana University - Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI). The students were paired with faculty mentors and engaged in research projects focused on cutting-edge cybersecurity issues, such as mobile computing and cloud security.

 

Students gained hands-on experience with advanced technologies, including private cloud computing facilities, mobile devices, and data analytics tools. Weekly one-on-one meetings with mentors ensured that each participant received personalized guidance. The program also offered seminars on specific technical skills, research colloquiums with invited speakers, and opportunities for students to present their work.

 

Broader Impacts:

This REU Site had a strong focus on diversity and inclusion, successfully recruiting students from underrepresented groups in STEM. Take 2023 as an example, 40% of the participants were from underrepresented groups, and 20% were first-generation college students. These efforts helped address the underrepresentation of minorities and women in computing fields, promoting a more inclusive computing workforce.

 

Project Outcomes:

The REU program achieved significant success in encouraging participants to pursue further education in computer science and engineering. As of 2023, several students have continued into graduate programs, with four requesting recommendation letters for graduate school. The program also resulted in five research papers being submitted to conferences, with several accepted for presentation. Students gained confidence in research communication, problem-solving, and collaboration, culminating in a self-organized workshop at the end of the summer.

 

In summary, this project provided an intellectually stimulating and diverse research experience that inspired students to pursue careers in mobile cloud security and further STEM education.
